description: Northwestern University Marching Band performs at the Northwestern Wildcats' game against the Michigan Wolverines at Dyche Stadium in Evanston, Illinois. Conducted by James Sudduth, the pregame performances include the "Hail to the Victors," "Let There Be Peace On Earth," the National Anthem, "I Write the Songs," and "Go U Northwestern." The halftime show is a tribute to George Gershwin and includes "Rhapsody in Blue," Strike Up the Band," and "Fascinating Rhythm." The Homecoming Court is announced as the band performs "Embraceable You." The Homecoming halftime concludes with "The Man I Love," "Summertime," and then John P. Paynter conducts "Alma Mater."

description: Two performances by the Northwestern University Marching Band during the 1983 season. First, the Northwestern University Marching Band performs at the Northwestern Wildcats' Homecoming game against the Minnesota Gophers at Dyche Stadium in Evanston, Illinois. Pregame performances begin with the University of Minnesota Marching Band performing "Go, Go for Victory" and "Minnesota Rouser." The Northwestern University Marching Band, conducted by Dale Lonis, performs the National Anthem, "Minnesota Rouser," and "Go U Northwestern." Halftime performances by the University of Minnesota Marching Band include "What a Feeling (Theme from Flashdance)" and "Truly" by Lionel Ritchie. The Northwestern University Marching Band performs "Give My Regards to Broadway" and "What a Feeling (Theme from Flashdance)." As the Homecoming court is announced, the band plays "Memory." The NUMB Alums join the band to play "Stars and Stripes Forever." Finally, John P. Paynter conducts "Alma Mater." The second performance is from the Northwestern Wildcats' game against the Purdue Boilermakers in West Lafayette, Indiana. Pregame performance by the Northwestern Marching Band include "Hail Purdue," "She Works Hard for the Money," and "Go U Northwestern." The Purdue University All-American Marching Band performs "Go U Northwestern," "Hail Purdue," the National Anthem, "America the Beautiful," and "Back Home Again in Indiana." Halftime performances by the Northwestern Marching Band include "Stars and Stripes Forever" and "Go U Northwestern." The Purdue Marching Band performs "Come Back to Me," "Muskrat Ramble," "Ta-Ra-Ra Boom-Dey-Ay," and "Hail Purdue." Postgame performances by both bands include "Hail Purdue," "Go U Northwestern," "What a Feeling (Theme from Flashdance)," "Salsation," "The Charleston," "Muskrat Ramble," "I Got the Music in Me," music from "Winds of War," "Fame," "For the Honor of Old Purdue," and "Alma Mater."

School of Music|Northwestern University (Evanston, Ill.)|Friedmann, Pete|Peterson, Stephen (Conductor)|Lloyd Webber, Andrew, 1948-|Paynter, John P.|Dvořák, Antonín, 1841-1904|Bernstein, Leonard, 1918-1990|Britten, Benjamin, 1913-1976
description: Two performances by the Northwestern University Marching Band during the 1990 season. First, the Northwestern University Marching Band performs at the Northwestern Wildcats' game against the Indiana Hoosiers at Dyche Stadium in Evanston, Illinois. Pregame performances include "Indiana Fight," "God Bless America," the National Anthem, and "Go U Northwestern." The halftime show is a tribute to composer Andrew Lloyd Webber and features selections from "Phantom of the Opera" including "Phantom of the Opera," "Think of Me," and "Music of the Night." From "Jesus Christ Superstar," the band performs "What's the Buzz," "Everything's Alright," "This Jesus Must Die," "King Herod's Song," and "Jesus Christ Superstar." The halftime show concludes with "Memory" from "Cats." John P. Paynter conducts the band for "Alma Mater." The second performance is from the Northwestern Wildcats' game against the Purdue Boilermakers at Dyche Stadium in Evanston, Illinois. Pregame performances include "Hail Purdue," "God Bless America," the National Anthem, and "Go U Northwestern." The theme of the halftime performance was classical music and included "Symphonic Dance #1," "Candide Overture," and "Young Person's Guide to the Orchestra." John P. Paynter conducts the band in "Alma Mater."

description: Northwestern University Marching Band performs at the Northwestern Wildcats' game against the Northern Illinois Huskies at Dyche Stadium in Evanston, Illinois. Conducted by Stephen Peterson, the pregame performances include "Huskie Fight Song," "God Bless America," the National Anthem, and "Go U Northwestern." The halftime show features music from Andrew Lloyd Webber's "Phantom of the Opera" including "Think of Me," "Music of the Night," and "Phantom of the Opera." Then high school marching bands from the Illinois and Wisconsin area join the Northwestern University Marching Band on the field for performances of "Drumbeat Jamboree," "Washington Post March," and "America the Beautiful." Stephen Peterson conducts "Alma Mater."

creator: Paynter, John P.|Northwestern University (Evanston, Ill.). School of Music|Northwestern University (Evanston, Ill.)
description: Northwestern University presents the Honors Concert of 1981 featuring the Northwestern University Symphony Orchestra conducted by Frederick Ockwell. Honors Concert. The Honors Concert features winners of competitions for each of the disciplines of the School of Music. The winner in each discipline is interviewed before the performance. Part 1: The first performance of "Concerto for bass tuba and orchestra" by Ralph Vaughan Williams features a tuba solo. Violinist Lisa Kartman is featured in a performance of "Poème for violin and orchestra, opus 25" by Ernest Chausson, conducted by her father, Emeritus Professor Myron Kartman. Flutist Susan Glaser performs "Concerto for flute and orchestra" by Carl Nielson. Part 2 features more performances by award winners. John Gordon Ross conducts the orchestra in "Essay for Orchestra No. 1 Opus 12 No. 2" by Samuel Barber. Part 3 features the premiere of composer Bruce Mahin's "Desires, for Tenor and Orchestra," conducted by Ockwell with vocals by Barrington Coleman. A soprano vocalist performs Puccini's aria "Tu che di gel sei cinta" from Turandot. A pianist performs "Concerto No. 2 for piano and orchestra in G minor, opus 22" by Camille Saint-Saëns. Music professor and bandleader John Phillip Paynter, named for John Phillip Sousa, began his musical studies at Northwestern, graduating with a Bachelor of Music degree in 1950 and a Master's in Theory and Composition in 1951. Upon graduation, Paynter joined NU's faculty as the Director of the Marching Band. During his career at Northwestern, Paynter taught classes in band music, conducting, and arranging. The John P. Paynter Collection consists of six series titled Biographical Materials, Office, Northwestern University "Wildcat" Marching Band (NUMB), Publications, Music, and Digital and Audio Visual Material.

abstract: Bainum worked as a high school and junior college band instructor before becoming a professor of music, Director of Bands, and Director of the glee clubs at Northwestern University in 1926. Bainum retired in 1953. The Glenn Cliffe Bainum Papers fill twenty-seven boxes and span Bainum's life, with the bulk of the papers dating between the 1930s and the 1960s. Most of the materials in this collection consist of correspondence, records and photographs from Bainum's professional life after he arrived at Northwestern. He kept detailed scrapbooks, especially in his early years at Northwestern, of programs and newspaper clippings relating to many of his activities. Boxes 1-12 and 22-27 of the collection are divided into ten series: Biographical, Correspondence, Northwestern University School of Music, Other Organizations, General, Sheet Music, Photographs, Reel-toReel Recordings, Movies, Oversize Scores, and Artifacts. An addition consists of boxes 13-21.

scope_and_contents: The Glenn Cliffe Bainum Papers fill twenty-seven boxes and span Bainum's life, with the bulk of the papers dating between the 1930s and the 1960s. Most of the materials in this collection consist of correspondence, records and photographs from Bainum's professional life after he arrived at Northwestern. He kept detailed scrapbooks, especially in his early years at Northwestern, of programs and newspaper clippings relating to many of his activities. Information about nearly all of his major career activities is documented in his papers.

description: Public Broadcasting Service's coverage of the 1979 Drum Corp International Championship from . Jim Peck and Steve Rondinaro host the televised coverage of performances. Four corps are featured on this recording. The corps are judged on horn line, drum line, and color guard. The Spirit of Atlanta from Georgia perform "Georgia On My Mind," "Sweet Georgia Brown," and "Let It Be Me." The Phantom Regiment from Illinois perform a selection of songs including "Sorcerer's Apprentice." The Blue Devils from California perform a selection of songs. The Santa Clara Vanguard from California perform a selection of songs including Verdi's "Requiem."

description: Goodyear Blimp footage of the January 1, 1996 Rose Bowl game between the Northwestern University Wildcats and the University of Southern California Trojans. After being undefeated in the Big Ten, the Northwestern Wildcats ultimately lost the Rose Bowl to the USC Trojans by a score of 32-41. Aerial footage of the pregame, the marching bands pregame performances, opening events of the Rose Bowl, and first quarter are included.

description: Public Broadcasting Service's coverage of the 1980 Drum Corp International Championship from Birmingham, Alabama. Part 3 features North Star from Massachusetts performing "Prelude to War," "Where Am I Going," "Cookout," "Still," and "Olé." The Guardsmen from Schaumburg-Hoffman Estates perform "Seahawk," "Tiger of San Pedro," "Xylophonia," "The Wasps," and "Greensleeves." The Garfield Cadets from New Jersey perform "One Voice," "Uncle Joe," "Fantasy," "Elk's Parade," and music from the movie "Ice Castles." The Cavaliers from Park Ridge, Illinois perform a selection of music including "Santa Esmeralda Suite."

description: Public Broadcasting Service's coverage of the 1980 Drum Corp International Championship from Birmingham, Alabama. Jim Peck, Steve Rondinaro, and Rita Moreno host the televised coverage of performances by the top 12 corps. Part 1 features an introduction to the championship, host predictions, and interviews. The 12 corps will be judged on horn line, drum line, and color guard. Part 1 features North Star from Massachusetts performing "Prelude to War," "Where Am I Going," "Cookout," "Still," and "Olé." The Guardsmen from Schaumburg-Hoffman Estates perform "Seahawk," "Tiger of San Pedro," "Xylophonia," "The Wasps," and "Greensleeves." WTTW Channel 11 interrupts the coverage with station identification and sponsorship information.

(George Michael), 1878-1942|Gershwin, George, 1898-1937|Gershwin, Ira, 1896-1983|Paynter, John P.|Owens, Don (Don D.)|Prima, Louis, 1910-1978|LaBarbera, John, 1945-
description: Highlights from the Northwestern University Marching Band performances during the 1985 season. Selections include the pregame performance from a game between the Northwestern Wildcats and the Iowa Hawkeyes featuring "Go U Northwestern" and "Wildcat Fantasy." A performance of "You're a Grand Old Flag" and "Yankee Doodle Dandy" as part of a tribute to Indiana Hoosiers. The Northwestern Homecoming performances include "Sing, Sing, Sing," Don Owens conducting the Vocal Jazz Ensemble in "Birdland," and the NUMB alums joining the marching band for "Bill Bailey Won't You Please Come Home." Another halftime performance features "My Kind of Town," "Tiger of San Pedro," and "New World Symphony." Performances from parent weekend features songs by George and Ira Gershwin including "Summertime," "Man I Love," "I've Got Rhythm," and "Rhapsody in Blue." Performances from the game against the Fighting Illini include "Go U Northwestern," "Wildcat Fantasy," "Yankee Doodle Dandy," "You're a Grand Old Flag," "Georgia on My Mind," and "Sing, Sing, Sing." John P. Paynter then conducts the band in "Alma Mater" and the finale "March of the Steelmen." Rehearsal performances in Dyche Stadium follow the highlights.
